metadata.document_name: 14. SNS PRODUCTS PRIVATE VS. IJAZ UDDIN
metadata.source_pdf: 14. SNS PRODUCTS PRIVATE VS. IJAZ UDDIN.pdf
metadata.court_name: HIGH COURT OF DELHI AT NEW DELHI
key_issues: Here are the main legal issues:

• Whether the replication filed by the plaintiff can be taken on record despite being filed beyond the maximum permissible period of 45 days from the date when the written statement was supplied to the plaintiff.
• Whether the Delhi High Court (OS) Rules, specifically Chapter VII Rule 5, governs the timeline for filing a replication in civil procedure cases.
• What is the correct date for counting the period for filing a replication: the date of supply of the written statement or the date when the written statement was permitted to be taken on record?
• Whether the judgments relied upon by the defendant in Ram Sarup Lugani and Atlanta Limited are applicable to the facts and circumstances of this case.
• What is the implication of the Joint Registrar's order allowing the defendant's application for condonation of delay in filing the written statement on the timely filing of the replication.
• Can a replication be filed despite being belatedly submitted under Order VIII Rule 1 of the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908?
• What is the effect of the 45-day limit prescribed under Chapter VII Rule 5 for filing a replication on the plaintiff's ability to file a replication in this case?
metadata.decision_summary:
**Case Summary: SNS Products Private Limited vs Ijaz Uddin**

**Background:**
The plaintiff, SNS Products Private Limited, filed a lawsuit against the defendant, Ijaz Uddin, seeking a permanent injunction to restrain him from infringing their trademark "SHAN E DELHI", "SHAN-A-DELHI" or any other mark identical or deceptively similar. The court granted an ex parte ad interim injunction and appointed Local Commissioners to seize and inventorize the infringing goods.

**Legal Issues:**

1. Whether the replication filed by the plaintiff is valid given it was filed beyond the maximum permissible period of 45 days from the date when the written statement was supplied.
2. Whether the delay in filing the replication can be condoned under Order VIII, Rule 1 of the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 (CPC).
3. The interpretation of Chapter VII, Rule 5 of the Delhi High Court (Original Side) Rules, 2018 regarding the maximum period for filing a replication.

**Arguments:**

* Defendant's counsel argued that the replication cannot be taken on record as it was filed beyond the 45-day period and relied on judgments in Ram Sarup Lugani v. Nirmal Lugani and Atlanta Limited v. National Highways & Infrastructure Development Corporation Limited.
* Plaintiff's counsel contended that the copy of the written statement was supplied to them only on May 17, 2022, and therefore, the time for filing replication should be counted from July 11, 2022 (the date when the written statement was permitted to be taken on record).

**Court Findings:**

* The court noted that Chapter VII, Rule 5 of the Delhi High Court (OS) Rules states that the replication shall be filed within 30 days of receiving the written statement.
* However, the court disagreed with the defendant's contention that the replication cannot be permitted to be taken on record after the exhaustion of the maximum prescribed period of 45 days, citing the judgment in Ram Sarup Lugani which dealt with a different issue.

**Decision:**
The court allowed the plaintiff's replication, holding that:

* The time for filing the replication starts from the date when the written statement was permitted to be taken on record (July 11, 2022).
* The defendant's reliance on judgments in Ram Sarup Lugani and Atlanta Limited is not applicable in this case.
* Since the plaintiff filed the replication within the permissible period from July 11, 2022, it is valid.

The court ordered that the replication be taken on record, paving the way for further proceedings in the case.

2023/DHC/000970
CS(COMM) 34/2022
Page 1 of 6
$~10
*
IN THE HIGH COURT OF DELHI AT NEW DELHI
%
Date of decision : 7th February, 2023
+
CS(COMM) 34/2022
SNS PRODUCTS PRIVATE
LIMITED
..... Plaintiff
Through:
Mr.Tejveer Singh Bhatia, Mr. Kunal
Vats and Ms. Tanya Arora,
Advocates.
versus
IJAZ UDDIN
..... Defendant
Through:
Mr. Shashank Khurana, Advocate
CORAM:
HON'BLE MR. JUSTICE AMIT BANSAL
AMIT BANSAL, J. (Oral)
CS(COMM) 34/2022
1.
The present suit has been filed seeking relief of permanent injunction
restraining the defendant from infringing the trademark of the plaintiff,
passing off his goods as that of the plaintiff, damages and other ancillary
reliefs.
2.
Summons in the suit were issued on 17th January, 2022, when this
Court granted ex parte ad interim injunction against the defendant
restraining him from using the impugned mark ‘SHAN E DELHI’, ‘SHAN-
A-DELHI’ or any other mark identical or deceptively similar to the
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:10.02.2023 16:52:41
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 2 ---
2023/DHC/000970
CS(COMM) 34/2022
Page 2 of 6
plaintiff’s trademark, ‘SHAN-E-DELHI’ /
. A
Local Commissioner was also appointed by this Court to seize and
inventorize the infringing goods. Vide order dated 2nd February, 2022 one
more Local Commissioner was appointed to visit another premises of the
defendant.
3.
The counsel appearing on behalf of the defendant entered appearance
on 26th April, 2022 and the Court directed for the written statement along
with an affidavit of admission/denial of documents to be filed within the
period permissible in law. The replication was directed to be filed within
fifteen days of the receipt of the written statement.
4.
The written statement was filed on behalf of the defendant on 26th
April, 2022 and copy of the same was supplied to the counsel for the
plaintiff on the same date. The written statement was filed belatedly and
therefore, it was accompanied by an application under Order VIII Rule 1 of
the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 (CPC) seeking condonation of delay of
27 days in filing the written statement.
5.
The aforesaid application was allowed by the Joint Registrar on 11th
July, 2022 while noting that the counsel for the plaintiff does not have any
objection to the same. Subsequently, replication was filed on behalf of the
plaintiff on 23rd July, 2022.
6.
Counsel for the defendant contends that the replication cannot be
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:10.02.2023 16:52:41
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 3 ---
2023/DHC/000970
CS(COMM) 34/2022
Page 3 of 6
taken on record as it was filed beyond the maximum permissible period of
45 days from the date when the written statement was supplied to the
plaintiff. He places reliance on Chapter VII Rule 5 of the Delhi High Court
(Original Side) Rules, 2018 (hereinafter ‘Delhi High Court (OS) Rules’), the
judgment of the Division Bench in Ram Sarup Lugani v. Nirmal Lugani,
2020 SCC OnLine Del 1353 and the judgment of a Co-ordinate Bench in
Atlanta Limited v. National Highways & Infrastructure Development
Corporation Limited, 2019 SCC OnLine Del 11276.
7.
Counsel for the plaintiff submits that the copy of the written statement
was supplied to him only on 17th May, 2022. The time for counting the
period for filing replication can only be counted from the date when the
written statement was permitted to be taken on record. In the present case,
the said date would be 11th July, 2022. He further submits that the aforesaid
judgments relied upon by the defendant are not applicable to the facts and
circumstances of the case.
8.
I have heard the counsels for the parties.
9.
To appreciate the submissions of the parties, a reference may be made
to the relevant portion of Chapter VII Rule 5 of the Delhi High Court (OS)
Rules, which is reproduced below:
“5. Replication. – The replication, if any, shall be filed within
30 days of receipt of the written statement. …”
10.
The Division Bench in Ram Sarup Lugani (supra) while considering
the aforesaid Rule came to the conclusion that the Rule 5 of the Delhi High
Court (OS) Rules is mandatory in nature and the replication cannot be
permitted to be taken on record after the exhaustion of the maximum
prescribed period of 45 days. The issue before the Division Bench was not
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:10.02.2023 16:52:41
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 4 ---
2023/DHC/000970
CS(COMM) 34/2022
Page 4 of 6
with regard to the date from which the period of 45 days for filing the
replication would begin. The issue before the Division Bench was in the
context of whether delay in filing the replication can be condoned beyond
the period of 45 days in terms of Rule 5 of Chapter VII of the Delhi High
Court (OS) Rules. Therefore, the observations of the Division Bench would
not be of any assistance to the defendant.
11.
I do not agree with the submission of the defendant that in all cases
the period for filing replication would commence from the date of written
statement being supplied by the defendant to the plaintiff in terms of Rule 5
of the Delhi High Court (OS) Rules. Undoubtedly, the language used in
Rule 5 of the Delhi High Court (OS) Rules is that the replication has to be
filed within 30 days from the receipt of the written statement. This may be
ordinarily so. However, where the written statement was filed beyond the
statutory time limit and was taken on record only upon an application for
condonation of delay being allowed by the Court, the aforesaid rule has to
be interpreted in a manner that the period of 30 days will begin from the
time the written statement is permitted to be taken on record.
12.
This issue may be examined from a different point of view as well.
There would be no requirement for the plaintiff to file a replication in the
event that the application seeking condonation of delay in filing written
statement is not allowed and the written statement is not taken on record.
The plaintiff would be required to file replication only once the condonation
in delay is allowed and the written statement is taken on record. Therefore, it
is axiomatic that the period for filing replication would only commence from
the date when the delay is condoned and the written statement is taken on
record.
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:10.02.2023 16:52:41
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 5 ---
2023/DHC/000970
CS(COMM) 34/2022
Page 5 of 6
13.
In the present case, the replication was filed by the plaintiff within 12
days after the written statement was taken on record. It was the defendant
who had filed the written statement in a belated manner and sought
condonation of delay for the same, which the counsel for the plaintiff fairly
did not oppose. Therefore, there is no basis for the defendant to object to the
replication being taken on record.
14.
Reliance has been placed by the counsel for the defendant on the
judgment in Atlanta Limited (supra). In the said case, the written statement
was already taken on record and the plaintiff had filed an application under
the provisions of Order VIII Rule 10 of the CPC for taking the written
statement off the record as the filing of the written statement was delayed
and the said application was dismissed. The counsel for the plaintiff therein
filed an application contending that the maximum permissible period of 45
days for filing replication should be counted from the date when the
application of the plaintiff for taking the written statement off the record was
dismissed. The said application was rejected by the Court. In the present
case the written statement though filed by the defendant earlier, was
permitted to be taken on record only on a subsequent date and the replication
was filed within 12 days from the said date. Therefore, reliance placed on
the judgment in Atlanta Limited (supra) is misplaced.
15.
Therefore, I do not find any merit in the submission of the defendant
that the replication filed by the plaintiff along with admission/denial of
documents not be taken on record. Accordingly, the replication is permitted
be taken on record.
16.
List on 2nd March, 2023.
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:10.02.2023 16:52:41
Signature Not Verified

--- PAGE 6 ---
2023/DHC/000970
CS(COMM) 34/2022
Page 6 of 6
I.A. 813/2022 (O-XXXIX R-1 & 2 of CPC)
17.
List for further proceedings on 2nd March 2023.
18.
Interim orders to continue.
AMIT BANSAL, J
FEBRUARY 7, 2023
rt/sr
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:10.02.2023 16:52:41
Signature Not Verified

tree_structure.summary:
**Case Summary:** SNS Products Private Limited (Plaintiff) vs. Ijaz Uddin (Defendant)

Source: PDF file titled "14. SNS PRODUCTS PRIVATE VS. IJAZ UDDIN.pdf"

**Case Details:**

* Case Header and Parties:
	+ Plaintiff: SNS Products Private Limited
	+ Defendant: Ijaz Uddin
	+ Advocates: Mr.Tejveer Singh Bhatia, Mr. Kunal Vats, Ms. Tanya Arora (Plaintiff) and Mr. Shashank Khurana (Defendant)
* Date of Decision: 7th February, 2023
* Case Number: CS(COMM) 34/2022

**Proceedings:**

1. The suit was filed on an ex parte ad interim injunction seeking relief to restrain the defendant from infringing the plaintiff's trademark and passing off goods as its own.
2. Summons were issued on January 17, 2022, with this Court granting ex parte ad interim injunction against the defendant.
3. A Local Commissioner was appointed on February 2, 2022, to seize and inventorize infringing goods.
4. The defendant's counsel entered appearance on April 26, 2022, and filed a belated written statement.
5. The joint registrar allowed an application for condonation of delay in filing the written statement on July 11, 2022.
6. Replication was filed by the plaintiff on July 23, 2022.

**Key Dates:**

* January 17, 2022: Summons issued
* February 2, 2022: Local Commissioner appointed
* April 26, 2022: Defendant's counsel entered appearance and filed written statement
* July 11, 2022: Application for condonation of delay allowed
* July 23, 2022: Replication filed

**Amounts:**

nodes.summary:
**Summary of Page 1 from PDF: 14. SNS PRODUCTS PRIVATE VS. IJAZ UDDIN.pdf**

Source: Delhi High Court Case Number 2023/DHC/000970 (CS(COMM) 34/2022)

The case involves a trademark infringement claim by **SNS Products Private Limited** against **Ijaz Uddin**. The plaintiff seeks:

1. Permanent injunction to prevent the defendant from using a mark identical or deceptively similar to SNS's trademark.
2. Damages and other ancillary reliefs.

On January 17, 2022, the Court granted an ex parte ad interim injunction against Ijaz Uddin, restraining him from using the impugned mark "SHAN E DELHI", "SHAN-A-DELHI" or any similar mark.

The case was decided by **Justice Amit Bansal** on February 7, 2023. 

Notable details:

* Date of decision: February 7, 2023
* Advocate's names:
	+ For the plaintiff: Tejveer Singh Bhatia, Kunal Vats, Tanya Arora
	+ For the defendant: Shashank Khurana

nodes.summary:
Here is a summary of page 2 from the PDF:

In the case CS(COMM) 34/2022, SNS Products Private Limited v. Ijaz Uddin, the court's proceedings are summarized as follows:

* A Local Commissioner was appointed to seize and inventory infringing goods on February 2, 2022.
* The defendant's counsel entered appearance on April 26, 2022, and filed a belated written statement with an application for condonation of delay under Order VIII Rule 1 of the Code of Civil Procedure, 1908 (CPC).
* The Joint Registrar allowed the application on July 11, 2022, noting that the plaintiff's counsel had no objection.
* A replication was filed by the plaintiff on July 23, 2022.

The focus is on legal facts and proceedings, specifically:

* Dates: February 2, 2022; April 26, 2022; July 11, 2022; July 23, 2022
* Parties involved: SNS Products Private Limited (plaintiff), Ijaz Uddin (defendant)
* Proceedings: Application for condonation of delay, filing of written statement and replication

tree_structure.title: Background and Facts
tree_structure.summary:
**Summary of Section: Background and Facts**

This is a court document from the High Court of Delhi at New Delhi (2023/DHC/000970). The case is:

**SNS Products Private Limited vs. Ijaz Uddin**

**Context:** CS(COMM) 34/2022, decided on February 7, 2023.

**Parties:**

* Plaintiff: SNS Products Private Limited
	+ Represented by Advocates Mr.Tejveer Singh Bhatia, Mr. Kunal Vats, and Ms. Tanya Arora.
* Defendant: Ijaz Uddin
	+ Represented by Advocate Mr. Shashank Khurana.

**Background:** The plaintiff seeks a permanent injunction against the defendant. However, the case revolves around the timeliness of filing a replication (reply to defendant's written statement).

**Decisions and Rulings:**

* The court takes note of Chapter VII Rule 5 of the Delhi High Court (Original Side) Rules, 2018.
* Counsel for the plaintiff argues that the copy of the written statement was supplied on May 17, 2022, and the time to file a replication should be counted from July 11, 2022, when it was permitted to be taken on record.
* The court upholds the defendant's position and rules that the replication cannot be taken on record after the maximum prescribed period of 45 days.

**Relevant Dates:**

* May 17, 2022: Written statement supplied to the plaintiff
* July 11, 2022: Date when written statement was permitted to be taken on record
* February 7, 2023: Decision date

This document is part of a PDF file named **14. SNS PRODUCTS PRIVATE VS. IJAZ UDDIN.pdf**
tree_structure.pdf_source: 14. SNS PRODUCTS PRIVATE VS. IJAZ UDDIN.pdf

nodes.title: Page 3
nodes.summary:
**Summary of Page 3 from PDF: 14. SNS PRODUCTS PRIVATE VS IJAZ UDDIN**

The defendant's written statement was taken on record beyond the maximum permissible period of 45 days, contrary to Chapter VII Rule 5 of the Delhi High Court (Original Side) Rules, 2018.

**Key points:**

* The written statement was filed beyond the 45-day limit.
* The defendant relies on Chapter VII Rule 5 and judgments in Ram Sarup Lugani and Atlanta Limited cases.
* The plaintiff disputes the applicability of these judgments to the present case.
* The plaintiff argues that the time for filing replication can only be counted from the date when the written statement was permitted to be taken on record.

**Court's consideration:**

The court will consider the relevant provisions of Chapter VII Rule 5 and make a decision based on the facts of the case.

**Source:** PDF document provided, specifically pages 2-3 of 6. The document is from the Delhi High Court, Case No. CS(COMM) 34/2022.

tree_structure.title: Legal Arguments
tree_structure.summary:
**Source:** Section: Legal Arguments from the PDF document "14. SNS PRODUCTS PRIVATE VS. IJAZ UDDIN.pdf"

**Case Details:**

* Case Number: CS(COMM) 34/2022
* Court: High Court of Delhi at New Delhi
* Date of Decision: February 7, 2023

**Parties:**

* Plaintiffs: SNS Products Private Limited (represented by Mr. Tejveer Singh Bhatia, Mr. Kunal Vats, and Ms. Tanya Arora)
* Defendant: Ijaz Uddin (represented by Mr. Shashank Khurana)

**Legal Arguments and Decisions:**

* The court was considering whether to accept a replication filed by the plaintiff in response to the defendant's written statement.
* The defendant argued that the period for filing replication should begin from the date of supply of the written statement, as per Rule 5 of Chapter VII of the Delhi High Court (OS) Rules. However, the court disagreed and ruled that the period would begin only when the delay in filing the written statement is condoned.
* The plaintiff's replication was filed within 12 days after the written statement was taken on record, which was permitted by the court.

**Outcome:**

* The replication filed by the plaintiff along with admission/denial of documents was permitted to be taken on record by the court.
* The interim orders would continue until further proceedings on March 2, 2023.
tree_structure.pdf_source: 14. SNS PRODUCTS PRIVATE VS. IJAZ UDDIN.pdf

nodes.title: Page 4
nodes.summary:
**Summary of Page 4 from PDF**

Source: 14. SNS PRODUCTS PRIVATE VS. IJAZ UDDIN.pdf (CS(COMM) 34/2022)

The page discusses a dispute over the commencement date for filing a replication in a civil case.

**Key Points:**

* The Division Bench's observations are not relevant to the defendant.
* The period for filing a replication does not necessarily commence from the date of written statement supply by the defendant.
* Where a written statement is filed beyond the statutory time limit, the 30-day period for filing a replication begins when the application for delay condonation is allowed and the written statement is taken on record.

**Important Dates:**

* February 7, 2023 (Date of decision)
* February 10, 2023 (Signing date)

**Names:**

* IJAZ UDDIN
* AMIT BANSAL

This summary focuses on legal facts and proceedings from page 4 of the PDF.

replication would begin. The issue before the Division Bench was in the
context of whether delay in filing the replication can be condoned beyond
the period of 45 days in terms of Rule 5 of Chapter VII of the Delhi High
Court (OS) Rules. Therefore, the observations of the Division Bench would
not be of any assistance to the defendant.
11.
I do not agree with the submission of the defendant that in all cases
the period for filing replication would commence from the date of written
statement being supplied by the defendant to the plaintiff in terms of Rule 5
of the Delhi High Court (OS) Rules. Undoubtedly, the language used in
Rule 5 of the Delhi High Court (OS) Rules is that the replication has to be
filed within 30 days from the receipt of the written statement. This may be
ordinarily so. However, where the written statement was filed beyond the

be interpreted in a manner that the period of 30 days will begin from the
time the written statement is permitted to be taken on record.
12.
This issue may be examined from a different point of view as well.
There would be no requirement for the plaintiff to file a replication in the
event that the application seeking condonation of delay in filing written
statement is not allowed and the written statement is not taken on record.
The plaintiff would be required to file replication only once the condonation
in delay is allowed and the written statement is taken on record. Therefore, it
is axiomatic that the period for filing replication would only commence from
the date when the delay is condoned and the written statement is taken on
record.

nodes.title: Page 5
nodes.summary:
**PDF Source:** 14. SNS PRODUCTS PRIVATE VS. IJAZ UDDIN.pdf (2023/DHC/000970)

**Case Details:**

* Case Number: CS(COMM) 34/2022
* Parties: SNS Products Private Limited (Plaintiff) vs. Ijaz Uddin (Defendant)
* Judge: Hon'ble Mr. Justice Amit Bansal

**Summary of Page 5:**

The defendant, Ijaz Uddin, objects to the plaintiff's replication based on a judgment in Atlanta Limited, stating that the written statement was filed belatedly and should not be recognized. However, the court holds that the written statement was allowed to be taken on record after being delayed, and the replication was filed within 12 days from that date.

**Key Points:**

* The written statement was permitted to be taken on record later than expected.
* The replication was filed within 12 days of the rescheduled date.
* Reliance on Atlanta Limited is deemed misplaced by the court.
* No merit in the defendant's objection, and the replication is allowed to be recorded.
nodes.content:
2023/DHC/000970
CS(COMM) 34/2022
Page 5 of 6
13.
In the present case, the replication was filed by the plaintiff within 12
days after the written statement was taken on record. It was the defendant
who had filed the written statement in a belated manner and sought
condonation of delay for the same, which the counsel for the plaintiff fairly
did not oppose. Therefore, there is no basis for the defendant to object to the
replication being taken on record.
14.
Reliance has been placed by the counsel for the defendant on the
judgment in Atlanta Limited (supra). In the said case, the written statement
was already taken on record and the plaintiff had filed an application under
the provisions of Order VIII Rule 10 of the CPC for taking the written
statement off the record as the filing of the written statement was delayed
and the said application was dismissed. The counsel for the plaintiff therein
filed an application contending that the maximum permissible period of 45
days for filing replication should be counted from the date when the
application of the plaintiff for taking the written statement off the record was
dismissed. The said application was rejected by the Court. In the present
case the written statement though filed by the defendant earlier, was
permitted to be taken on record only on a subsequent date and the replication
was filed within 12 days from the said date. Therefore, reliance placed on
the judgment in Atlanta Limited (supra) is misplaced.
15.
Therefore, I do not find any merit in the submission of the defendant
that the replication filed by the plaintiff along with admission/denial of
documents not be taken on record. Accordingly, the replication is permitted
be taken on record.
16.
List on 2nd March, 2023.
Digitally Signed By:AMIT
BANSAL
Signing Date:10.02.2023 16:52:41
Signature Not Verified
